note.p: Français 1740, Bibliothéque national de France, Paris. Paris, 1401-1402.

The parchment presents a yellow tonality, especially around the edges. It has many defects such as spots, holes carefully repaired (ff. 17, 25, and 28) and cuts. The irregularities in the dimension of the folios indicates that they were not trimmed during binding. The rule vis-à-vis is respected half the time.
32 + I. Modern foliation in ink on the top right corner is accurate. It was probably added in the 18th century.

There are uniform light gray ruling marks on the folios done with a lead pencil. There is some evidence of pricking, with 2 or 4 rather big pricks on the folios of circular or eliptical form. There is one column with 32 (sometimes 30 to 41) lines.

The text is written in brown ink and the rubrics are pink. There seems to be one scribal hand for the whole manuscript (Hand X) using a very controlled calligraphic cursive script. There is little evidence of punctuation marks, but there are plenty corrections done by the scribe's own hand.

There is a large pen-flourished initial P at the beginning of the manuscript (fol. 1) in light blue, with red, black and dark blue flourishes. There are also traces of gilding. In addition, there are four smaller pen-flourished initials (ff. 7, 15, 16, and 31) alternating the colour scheme between red initial with blue flourishes and vice-versa.

Only one miniature decorates the manuscript on folio 1, Christine presenting her manuscript to the Duque of Orleans, painted in grisaille by the workshop of the Master of the Coronation of the Virgin.

The manuscript was bound with yellow moroccan leather with the coat of arms surrounded by three golden fillets on the cover. There are 5 nerves on the spine, with the initials of the Louis XIV surmounted by a small star. The title appears also in the spine, over an applied piece of red leather, reading "LE DE/BAT D D'A/M'P CH/D'PIS".
The manuscript can be dated between 1401 and 1402. It is the oldest surviving copy of this text, even earlier than the copy in Chantilly Ms. 492, completed in 1402.

Provenance: The manuscript belonged without a doubt to Louis d'Orléans. It contains previous shelfmarks on folio 1: 1023 (Rigault), 980 (Dupuy); 7692 (Regius). There is a stamp from the royal library dated around 1724.
It only contains Le debat de deux amans.
*The information given here comes from direct observation and from Ouy, Gilbert, Christine Reno and Inès Villela-Petit. Album Christine de Pizan . Turnhout: Brepols, 2012.
